video.title: Linux Operating System - Crash Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn the basics of the Linux Operating System in this crash course for beginners. Linux is a clone of the UNIX operating system, so understanding one is understanding the other. The goal is for you to get a full understanding of how the Linux OS works. If you're still using Windows or Mac OS, you can still learn Linux using a virtual machine.

✏️ Course from KeepItTechie. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCP2bshADPrVMoNrdJvZEQzw

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:08:09) Install Linux
⌨️ (0:29:43) Desktop Environment
⌨️ (0:41:18) Terminal
⌨️ (0:49:25) Working with Directories
⌨️ (1:15:49) Working with Files
⌨️ (1:34:49) Working with File Content
⌨️ (1:51:14) Linux File Structure
⌨️ (2:03:68) System Information
⌨️ (2:15:42) Networking
⌨️ (2:20:10) Linux Package Manager
⌨️ (2:34:10) Text Editor
⌨️ (2:46:56) Outro

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Aldo Luna Bueno
topLevelComment.text:
49:32 _man_ (manual)
  The most important of all commands. It gives the manual of a command. First try _man man_.

DIRECTORIES

1:01:26 _ls -a_
   The command _ls -a_ shows all the files whether they're hidden or don't. Hide a file by naming it with a period at the start (ex: .gitignore). 
1:10:55 _mkdir -p Grandfather/father/child_
  Make a child folder within a parent or secuence of parent folders one inside the other even if these don't exist.
1:14:57 _rmdir -p Grandfather/father/child_
  If there are more than one empty child folder, the parent folder isn't deleted. If you want to delete a folder and all its content, use this: _rm -rf directory_name_
1:16:56 Everything in Linus OS is a file. Directories are considered special files.

FILES

1:22:02 _touch file1 file2 file3_
  Create multiple files.
1:25:25 _rm -rf directory_
  Remove a non-empty directory. The options -r (recursive) and -f (force) will recursively force the deleting the folders and files inside.
1:31:06 _mv_
  The common use is just move a file to other directory: _mv file /other/directory_
  But many people use this command to rename files: _mv file file_renamed_
  You can also rename and move a file all at once: _mv file /other/directory/file_renamed_
  The absolute path is needed, so you can use ~ to avoid the _/home/username_ part of the path.
1:40:17 _cat file1 file2 file3 > output_file_
  You can can concatenate several files and print it to the console _(cat file1 file2 file3)_ or print it to another file (a new one is created if doesn't exist), like the complete command above.
  You can also omit the files and just create a new one that then you must to fill on terminal (Ctrl+D to finish): _cat > new_file_
  A similar way to create (if doesn't exist) and fill a file on terminal is with _echo_ command: _echo strings... > new_file_

You can reference a file by its exact name, and it matches just one file, but you can also reference multiple files by a regular expresion (a expresion with special characters like *). For example, you can delete all text files in a directory with this command: _rm *.txt_

FILE STRUCTURE

1:56:53 _lib/_
  It's like _Program files_ on Windows: a  folder that contains all that's needed to run a program.
1:59:02 _root/_
  It's the home of the root account.
2:02:12 _usr/_
  Stores files and utilities that are shared between users.
2:02:28 _var/_
It's where variable data is stored, usually system logs.

SYSTEM INFORMATION

2:06:32 _free -h_
  Shows the use of memory, and the option _-h_ is to make it human-readable.
2:08_06 _ps -A_
  Shows a snapshot of all proccess, all with a unique ID. The you can kill a proccess by tha command _kill <proccessID>_

NETWORKING

2:18:50 _ip_
  The newest version of the _ifconfig_ command.

PACKAGE MANAGER

2:20:45 _sudo_
  Stands for _super user do._ It's used to access to restricted files and operations.

replies.author: Javier Flores
replies.text:
For the vast majority of computer users, the graphical interface is much easier and simpler to use than the command line. However, if you want to go deep into how your computer works or if you're interested in higher level IT jobs, knowing your way around a command line is invaluable. 

As an example, let's say you want to create 20 folders. With the graphical interface, you right click an empty part of your desktop, and create a new folder. Pretty easy. However, you will quickly realize that doing that 19 more times is very tedious. With the command line, you can write out a script that will create 20 folders at once. I don't have a particular script to show you, but it can be done that way. It is tedious and does take a long time and practice to get good at it. However, if you do become proficient in the command line, you'll find that certain tasks are very quickly achieved through there rather than the graphical interface.

replies.author: Henry
replies.text:
>It appears to be very manual setup

installing an operating system on a real computer is doing some manual stuff.
virtualbox behaves like a real simulated computer here...

oh and to get real fullscreen you need to install the GUEST ADDITIONS inside the virtualized linux.

replies.author: Henry
replies.text:
in other words: virtualbox is simulating a computer inside your computer.
and to install ubuntu you can insert the virtual DVD *.iso file into the virtualbox computer.

you have to learn how to operate the virualbox computer ... like how define a new computer profile, how insert the DVD iso, how "install" a virtual HDD (which will also just be a file where the data is stored) etc., how to bind a local port to the VM if you want to reach a server inside the vm etc. And learn about SNAPHOTS in virtualbox, best thing to rollback stuff to a clean state after testing things...

replies.author: Robert E.
replies.text:
So, most people turn on their comp and their OS (windows, linux, whatever) eventually loads.  This is because pressing the power button basically initiates BIOS on the motherboard and then BIOS initiates the OS on the hard drive.  

With a "Virtual Box" the OS isn't on the hard drive, but some other media (typically a Flashdrive/USB stick or a DVD).  So you press the power button, that initiates the BIOS on the motherboard,  and then the BIOS initiates the OS *on the virtualbox* (e.g. flashdrive/USB stick), completely bypassing the hard drive altogether.

With this setup, you can forever use Linux on the Virtualbox and never truly install it on your comp, OR, from the virtualbox, you can then install Linux on your harddrive (which is sort of synonymous saying that your installing it on your comp).

In this situation,  the OS the computer is running is not Windows, or MacOS, or whatever, it's the Linux distro (e.g. Ubuntu, RedHat, etx.) on the Virtualbox media.

You can install Linux (or really ANY OS) on a computer in addition to Windows (for example installing multiple harddrives each with its own OS or one large harddrive with correct "partitions"), but regardless of the method, with this type of setup, you can only boot into one OS at a time.*

*when properly done, each time your comp starts up, you go into BIOS and select which OS you want to load, or you can sort of throw a tiny program inbetween the BIOS to OS sequence, a program like GRUB for example, so after the BIOS starts, it starts GRUB and then GRUB says, "hey, user, you got more than one OS on this thing.  Which one would you like to boot into today?"

topLevelComment.author: Joseph Steinhauser
topLevelComment.text:
2:07:55 To show "ps" list of processes, it is more useful to use "ps -eaf" rather than "ps -A" to show memory use, CPU time, how long ago started, user-ID, and more.
This usually outputs several pages of text, so you may also want to pipe it through grep, less, awk, or sort+head, to focus on the processes you want.
The "pstree" command will show which procs are related to each other, as parent & child, in a branch/indented tree.
For a quick screen of the heaviest process load on your machine... use command "top" which shows top CPU use, updated every 10 seconds. (press "q" to quit)

replies.author: Tanmay Panadi
replies.text:
Use what works for your workflow. 
there are pros and cons to everything.

IMO.

linux is for people who like their privacy and support open-source software .

it just works on any hardware let it be 10 years old or new.
you can customize the system for what you want to do and how you want to do it no restrictions at all. 
it has really great speeds when ever I want to move large no of small files or just a big file around. 
the network stack and options are very nice when using it for torrents and working with files.

The Linux filesystems like BTRFs and Ext4, ZFS is more advance and newer than NTFS. it is build with multiple users in mind.
ZFS and BTRFS files backups and restore functions that actually work unlike windows.

windows is really great for Adobe suite and gaming point of view.

topLevelComment.author: Hans Müller
topLevelComment.text:
Good that he talked a bit about Stallman. But he should have explained what free software actually means.
Free has multiple meanings in english and in this case, it is about rights. It's not free as in free beer. Thus, sometimes free software is called libre software.
Stallman recommends to watch his TED talk in which he explained the importance of free software.
So yeah. Btw. if you are a new user you might want to join a community (forum, reddit, chat platform). By regularly checking a community, you will see what other people share and thus you might learn new things every few days. I for instance am active in the Linux Gaming community on Matrix and Discord (tho discord is not a good platfom and unfree software..).

replies.author: Tanmay Panadi
replies.text: there is also a Level1linux Channel and Level1techs Forum's. it is really great place to hang out and nerd out.

replies.author: Osama Abbas
replies.text:
Stick with Mint. Save yourself the frustration of Ubuntu (or Gnome 3 to be exact). Mint/Cinnamon is far better than Ubuntu/Gnome.

In the recent decade or so, Gnome has the habit of looking for any program that works just find, discarding it, and then they proceed to build an inferior version of it, with about 5% of its original functionality!

Just compare Gnome Files to the original old Nautilus (Or Nemo in Mint).

Tl;dr: Stick with Mint/Cinnamon, Gnome is trash.

I don't think this will work. Chrome is running on ARM processors. You'd have to use a Arm version of Windows.

replies.author: Qazi Zayad
replies.text:
Purchase a bootable windows USB installer or get windows iso file online and make a bootable USB with that iso written on it. 

Then access your Computer's BIOS and change it's boot order, in order to boot from the USB. Then windows installer window will be in front of you. Then proceed with the onscreen instructions.
